"The residents agreed.''</p><p>During the night, fire destroyed a garage and an older model vehicle south of the community, but no homes have been burned, she said. Six bulldozers and 50 firefighters defended the hamlet's southern limits Saturday as water bombers hammered back the flames.</p><p>"They did some excellent work along the southern edge of the fire there right on the edge of the town,'' Toker said. "They have established a fire guard around the perimeter of the community and that will serve the people well.'' A municipal fire truck waited on standby Saturday to protect the buildings in the community. Toker said it was complemented by a rapid fire unit that uses compressed foam to protect the structures in the community.</p><p>Firefighters are also trying to protect another 12 unoccupied summer cottages in the area.</p><p>Chisholm is on the northern boundary of the 120 square kilometre fire that is now under attack from 200 firefighters and a fleet of helicopters, planes and heavy equipment.</p><p>Thirteen residents of Flatbush, about 20 km to the south, have been placed on evacuation alert, but winds blowing out of the east Saturday gave them some respite.</p><p>"If necessary they will be instructed when it may be time to leave,'' Toker said from the scene as two CL-215 water bombers roared overhead.</p><p>About 30 people evacuated from farms north of Flatbush Friday have been allowed to return to their homes, but remain on evacuation alert, she said.</p><p>"We're dealing with a fire and conditions that could change at a moment's notice,'' she added. "While we're doing good work out here right now, we're taking every precaution. This is the largest fire we've had in Alberta this year.''</p><p>The Chisholm residents have been billeted with friends and family in the neighbouring towns of Smith and Slave Lake. Access to the community is blocked by manned barricades.</p><p>"Because of the operations we have in the area, it's best we keep people back,'' Toker said. "As soon as it is safe to get back in, the residents will be notified.''</p><p>Meanwhile, Transport Canada investigators were able to return on Saturday to the scene of a plane crash that killed two people who had been helping fight another fire Friday.</p><p>RCMP removed the bodies of the unidentified pilot and passenger of a forest fire spotter plane that crashed on the edge of fire burning northeast of Red Earth Creek, but had to evacuate the area when the fire came within a half kilometre.</p><p>The Cessna went down in dense forest in a hilly area near Trout Mountain. Police said visibility in the area was affected by fire smoke.</p><p>Red Earth Creek is about 425 km north of Edmonton.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata NORTH BAY - UPDATE (3:30 P.M. Sunday, July 29) The Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry have remapped the North Bay 72 in the Lady Evelyn Fire Cluster.

Shortly after 3 p.m. today the MNR remapped the cluster to 27,275, slightly smaller than what was reported earlier this morning.

#NorthBay 72 in the Lady Evelyn fire cluster is remapped to 27,275 hectares. Visit our https://t.co/XPnoZFTS24 page for updated information. #forestfires #ontario pic.twitter.com/PawIhPaTgn - ONForestFires (@ONforestfires) July 29, 2018

NORTH BAY - UPDATE (8:46 a.m. Sunday, July 29) By the evening of Saturday, July 28 there were 39 active forest fires across the northeast. of these, 12 are not yet under control, 27 are either being held, under control or are being observed.

There were no new forest fires discovered on July 28.

River Valley Fire Cluster

Crews made solid progress on all fires today. North Bay 62 was deemed under control on the morning of Saturday, July 28. Crews worked on the north side of North Bay 42 and made good progress. NOR 025 is also under control.

Lady Evelyn Fire Cluster

North Bay Fire 072 remains at 27,579 hectares and is listed as not under control. A little bit of smoke was observed on the fire later in the afternoon of Saturday, July 28 and the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry anticipates that will increase over the next few days as the weather returns to seasonal values and temperatures reach the mid to high 20s. There are 11 helicopters assigned to this cluster.

NORTH BAY - UPDATE (9 a.m., Saturday, July 28) By the evening of Friday, July 27 the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry reports there were 43 forest fires across the northeast. Of these, 13 are not yet under control, 30 are either being held under control or being observed.

There was one new fire confirmed, North Bay 119, located eight kilometres southwest of Lachford was 0.1 hectares and is already out.

A total of three fires were extinguished today.

River Valley Fire Cluster

This cluster includes two fires - North Bay 62 and North Bay 42. Both of these fires are being held. North Bay 25 is being monitored to the west of the cluster, which is now under control at 200 hectares.

There are 135 people working on these fires including firefighters from Ontario, Alberta, British Columbia, Nova Scotia, Saskatchewan and Mexico.

Crews made progress on all fires in the cluster today working on the southside of North Bay 42 and continued to work the perimeter on North Bay 62 while other crews continued to recover equipment from the fire.

Some smoke was visible on North Bay 25 while crews worked to extinguish hot spots.

Lady Evelyn Fire Cluster

The North Bay 72 fire remains at 27,579 hectares and is not yet under control. The fire was scanned from the air in the early morning of July 27. Infrared scanning identifies areas that are holding heat so fire rangers can walk the fire and extinguish hot spots.

The Incident Management Team assigned to this cluster continues to observe North Bay fires 18, 19, 46, 59, and 61. These fires will also be scanned using infrared technology in the coming days.

NORTH BAY - UPDATE (11:55 p.m., Thursday, July 26): By the evening of Thursday, July 26, there were 45 active forest fires across northeast Ontario. Of these, 15 are not yet under control, 30 are either being held, under control or being observed.

River Valley Fire Cluster

The River Valley Fire Cluster includes two fires: North Bay 62 and North Bay 42. Both fires are now being held, meaning that the fires are not expected to spread under current conditions. The ministry is continuing to monitor North Bay 25 to the west of the cluster, which is now under control.

There are 154 people working on these fires including firefighters from Ontario, British Columbia, Alberta, Saskatchewan, Nova Scotia and Mexico.

Crews took advantage of the cooler, dry day to make solid progress on all fires. On North Bay 42, crews continued to secure the perimeter on the north side as well as working on hot spots on the west side. For North Bay 62, crews continued to work the perimeter of the fire while some crews began to recover equipment from the fire.

Crews completed removal of sprinkler protection from all structures.

Temagami Fire Cluster:

Fire activity has proven more manageable on fires in the Temagami cluster with all active fires in this cluster now classified as either being held or under control.

Lady Evelyn Fire Cluster:

North Bay 72 remains at 27,579 hectares and is listed as not under control. However, the overcast skies and wet weather of late has allowed firefighters to consolidate hose lines along the perimeter. While there is much work still to be done, progress is being made daily.

Front line staff continue to work with heavy equipment operators to establish dozer guards in areas where this type of suppression is suitable. This goes a long way to secure the perimeter of the fire.

The Incident Management Team continues to observe North Bay 18, 19, 46, 59 and 61. While these fires have been quiet, they are not considered out.

Currently there are 10 helicopters assigned to this cluster. Transitioning of staff is ongoing as personnel depart for their home locations and new staff arrive. Crews arrived from northwestern Ontario today and more are expected from Saskatchewan tomorrow.

The ministry continues to have firefighters from British Columbia, Alberta, Ontario, Nova Scotia, Newfoundland, Northwest Territories and Mexico work on this cluster. Restricted Fire Zone expanded

Due to the extreme fire hazard, several recent periods of heavy lightning, little precipitation and increased forest fire, the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry has expanded the Restricted Fire Zone. This expansion of the current Restricted Fire Zone will be in effect as of 12:01 a.m. on Tuesday, July 24, and remain in place until further notice.

The expanded Restricted Fire Zone now includes Zones 24, 25 and 26 which would include areas south of the French River, including Parry Sound, from Georgian Bay east to the Quebec border, including Algonquin Provincial Park and from Renfrew north to Mattawa.

To date, the current Restricted Fire Zone covers Zones 16, 17, 18, 19, 20, 21, 24, 25 and 26 and restrictions will remain in place until further notice. See the fire map for an outline of the zones covered.

During a Restricted Fire Zone, the use of open fires - such as campfires, or burning of brush or debris, is restricted. Failure to comply could result in fines of up to $25,000 and three months in jail, as well as financial responsibility for the costs incurred in fighting a forest fire.

Portable gas or propane stoves are permitted for use for cooking or warmth, though they should be closely monitored. Portable charcoal barbecues and Hibachis are not permitted unless within 100 metres of a dwelling, or within an organized campground.

Commercial campground operators may allow their guests to enjoy campfires during a Restricted Fire Zone period provided they meet certain conditions in the Outdoor Fires Regulation (207/96).

The Restricted Fire Zone is a temporary measure to reduce the number of new human-caused wildfires as the Aviation Forest Fire and Emergency Services branch of the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry expects the elevated forest fire hazard to continue into the foreseeable future.

Ontario is receiving support from across Canada, the United States and Mexico to assist with the fire situation. Additional personnel and equipment are expected to arrive in the province in the coming days, including ignition specialists from Parks Canada.

Travel restrictions

Pursuant to the Emergency Area Order signed July 21, an Implementation Order has been issued by the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry prohibiting access and travel in portions of North Bay, Kirkland Lake and Sudbury Districts where there are public safety hazards as a result of increased fire activity.

The Order restricts travel, access and use in an identified area and may be modified regularly to reflect changing fire conditions.

This measure has been put in place to ensure public safety while allowing fire personnel to safely and effectively suppress the fires in the identified area.

All travel and use of the following roads are prohibited: McLaren's Road, Gibbons Road, Baie-Jeanne Road, South Pardo Road, Beauty Lake Road, St. Joseph's Road, George Gordon and Iron Lake Road, Cooke Lake Road, Liskeard Lumber Road, Klock Lake Road, Crane Lake Road, Roadhouse Tower Road, Indian Bay Road, Mountain Lake Road, and Goulard Road starting at Lower Goose Falls.

All modes of travel/access into Lady Evelyn-Smoothwater, Obabika River, Makobe-Grays River, Solace and Sturgeon River Provincial Parks, and all Crown lands is prohibited.

Use of the Red Squirrel Lake Road beyond the Barmac Gate is prohibited.

All use and occupation of Crown land on or within 500 metres of all described closed roads is prohibited.

If a member of the public believes that access within the restricted travel area is necessary for non-recreational purposes, please call North Bay District at 705-475-5546 (8:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.) or Kirkland Lake District at 705-568-3240 (8:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.) to request a travel authorization permit. For requesting access to Red Squirrel Lake Road, please call North Bay District. MNRF will review the request for access based on the rationale provided, local fire activity, and the potential fire risk.

See the restricted travel and access areas on this PDF map (Note: this map gets updated regularly).

Smoke concerns

Many Ontario residents have reported smoke drift in their communities. Smoky conditions are expected to continue as a number of fires remain active throughout the northeast region until weather patterns and fire activity change.

The Aviation Forest Fire and Emergency Services branch of the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry is reminding the public that if they do see flames or smoke, please report it, and stay away from the area in the interest of public safety.

If you have questions or concerns about smoke and your health, please contact Tele Health Ontario at 1-866-797-0000.

To report a forest fire located north of the French and Mattawa rivers, please dial 310-FIRE (3473)

To report a forest fire located south of the French or Mattawa rivers, please dial 911.

Follow Aviation Forest Fire and Emergency Services branch of the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry on Twitter @ONForestFires

For up to date information on current fires in the province or to check the forest fire hazard in your area, visit Ontario.ca/forestfire.

(CP) _ A standard-sized campfire ignited the 25-hectare forest fire that forced 500 people from their homes last weekend, investigators have found.</p><p nitf:lede="true">RCMP, the Westside fire department, B.C. Forest Service and the regional district had been trying to pinpoint the cause since the fire flared up in Rose Valley Regional Park last Saturday night.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"There's no evidence of a huge party fire,'' said fire information officer Dale Bojahra. "It looked like a pretty standard campfire.''</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>The fire was illegal because there's a campfire ban in the regional park.</p><p>Investigators are fairly certain the culprits started the campfire on Saturday evening because witnesses told RCMP they'd been by the site earlier in the afternoon and there was no fire.</p><p>"Those same individuals said they could see a campfire-sized fire in that area from across the lake (that evening),'' said Bojahra.</p><p>No beer cans were found nearby. Investigators discovered two freshly eaten cobs of corn and a tin can with unknown contents.</p><p>Meanwhile, airborne firefighters using infrared scanners spotted 15 small hot spots Friday morning that were still smouldering from the Westside blaze.</p><p>"The hot spots were all well into the interior of the fire, and well away from its edge,'' said Bojahra.</p><p>Crews in helicopters dropped flagged stakes onto the hot spots, none of which are bigger than 30 centimetres in diameter, and also passed along co-ordinates to firefighters on the ground.</p><p>Fewer than a dozen firefighters are now working to fully extinguish the blaze.</p><p>Next week, fire crews will do some remediation work, trying to return the fireguards and equipment access lines to a more natural state.</p><p>"We don't want to leave these huge scars on the land,'' Bojahra said. The fire risk throughout the Okanagan is now rated as low because of recent rains and cool temperatures.</p><p>"But it could still climb up into the moderate or even high range in September, depending what kind of weather we have,'' Bojahra said.</p><p>(Kelowna Daily Courier)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata There are 88 actively burning, although none currently threatens a community.</p><p>Meanwhile, in northwestern Ontario, firefighters continue to battle a fire south of Minaki.</p><p>Escorted traffic was being allowed in and out of the area. Cottagers were being allowed into Pelican Pouch Lake, but Catherine Lake where the fire began last Sunday is still not open. Five cottages went up in flames at Catherine Lake.</p><p>(Winnipeg Free Press)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">CAPRSS-20030823CPCPD3768</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">CAPRSS2003</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:49C3-T910-01G6-92DM-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">253760</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2020-06-24</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="214"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>The Canadian Press (CP)</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 2003 Press News Limited, All Rights Reserved</copyright><publicationDate day="23" month="08" year="2003"><dateText>August 23, 2003 Saturday</dateText></publicationDate><classification classificationScheme="publicationtype"><classificationItem><className>Newswires & Press Releases</className></classificationItem></classification></publicationInfo><classification classificationScheme="language"><classificationItem><className>ENGLISH</className></classificationItem></classification><classificationGroup classificationScheme="licensor.indexing-terms"><classification classificationScheme="licensor.subject"><classificationItem><className>HEALTH; urn:contentItem:7W88-SX01-2R6R-542J-00000-00Forest fire threats in B.C. helping drive up lumber prices, futures climbing2009-07-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:55:07ZLexisNexisBUSINESSForest fire threats in B.C. helping drive up lumber prices, futures climbingBRENDA BOUWCP

VANCOUVER _ The threat of more forest fires in British Columbia is helping drive up the price of lumber on world markets as speculators factor in a potential drop in supply.

''A forest fire in the lumber industry is equivalent to a draught in the grain industry where the grains spike up in price,'' said Ashley Boeckholt, an analyst with Bloch Lumber in Chicago.

''There is a tremendous potential for the price to go up if (more fires) happen.''

Boeckholt said the price of lumber has been climbing steadily since last week as fires ravage some parts of B.C.'s southern Interior around Kelowna.

The fire danger rating is considered ''extreme'' in areas of B.C.'s southern Interior, and will likely remain with the current heat wave across the province expected to continue for several days.

September lumber futures were trading at around $207 on Tuesday, which is up from $197 on Monday and $189 a week ago.

Boeckholt said while other factors _ including a recent string of positive U.S. housing data _ are behind the rising lumber prices, futures traders are watching the forest fire situation in B.C. closely.

''The end user is very tentative right now,'' said Boeckholt.

''Any disruption along that chain would cause a pretty severe supply shock in the market, which, at these low numbers, would cause a tremendous knee-jerk reaction and move up pretty high.''

He said the amount of B.C. forests that the mountain pine beetle has eaten up, making the wood brittle and more susceptible to fire, is also a concern.

''There's a lot of fuel with all this beetle kill sitting out there,'' he said.

Meantime, B.C. lumber producers are bracing themselves for potential Mother-Nature related shutdowns if the fire-hazard conditions persist.

Provincial regulations force producers to shut operations if the fire hazard is too high in an area where they are working, and special conditions must be met.

Murray Wilson, woodlands manager at Tolko Industries in B.C.'s Okanagan region, said any forced shutdown due to fire will be more bad news for the already struggling industry.

The forestry sector has been hammered in recent years from the U.S. housing slump, the high Canadian dollar, and a 15 per cent tax on B.C. forestry companies as a result of the Canada-U.S. softwood lumber deal.

''Anything that adds uncertainty and cost ... we just can't afford those things at this time,'' said Wilson.

He said the company stopped some operations for a day or two recently, as a result of fire threats.

''We see the potential for the fire hazard to build again and are being very cautious,'' Wilson said.

Russell Taylor, president of International Wood Markets Group Inc., a forestry consulting group, said B.C.'s forest industry accounts for about 15 per cent of U.S. lumber consumption.

He said a fire closure could not only put a dent in production but also impact log inventory for the fall.

''It doesn't take much to upset the apple cart at least in the near term,'' Taylor said.

And while some companies are curtailing production on their own as a result of depressed lumber markets, Taylor said it's different than being forced to cut back by Mother Nature.

''Companies can shut down at any time they want. The trouble is when you curtail you benefit someone else, which is why you always want to stay in the game,'' said Taylor.

(AP) - A runaway forest fire eating its way toward Mount Rushmore today and prompted evacuation of up to 1,000 residents and tourists near the national memorial, authorities said.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The fire, accelerated by dry timber from the drought afflicting the North American plains, has already charred more than 3,200 hectares (8,000 acres).</p><p>"When we told them (residents and campers) it was burning 1,000 acres per hour … and it was three miles away, they kind of believed us," said Sgt. Howard Brunner of the Pennington County Sheriff's Department, who helped evacuate the town of Keystone.</p><p>The blaze, which shot billows of smoke so high its pall was visible 256 kilometres (160 miles) away, also threatened the park's Game Lodge, summer White House for two presidents. No structures have been destroyed.</p><p>"It's a very serious situation," Jerry Hagen, fire information officer with the U.S. Forest Service, said early today.</p><p>The fire in Custer State Park and the Black Hills National Forest was within 4 kilometres (3 miles) of Mount Rushmore this morning. All entrances to the park were closed yesterday.</p><p>"The fire is extremely erratic and very frustrating to fight," Hagen said.</p><p>Brunner said the pace of the fire was slowed somewhat this morning when the winds shifted back toward the fire.</p><p>About 400 firefighters battled the fire in a steep, rocky area yesterday, but were forced to abandon their lines at nightfall. About 1,000 firefighters were expected to be on the scene early today.</p><p>Smoke was billowing thousands of feet into the air and the plume was visible from Rapid City 40 kilometres (25 miles) away.</p><p>A haze from the smoke hung over a large part of western South Dakota and was visible from Pierre, 256 kilometres (160 miles) urn:contentItem:5V5F-19P1-F103-34N9-00000-00Study finds human impact played major role in 2017 wildfire season2019-01-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:55:07ZLexisNexisNEWSStudy finds human impact played major role in 2017 wildfire season

Human influences played a major role in B.C.'s 2017 wildfire season and significantly increased the risk of wildfires, says a study by research scientists from the Pacific Climate Impacts Consortium at the University of Victoria and Environment and Climate Change Canada.

The study, which compared two scenarios in climate simulations - one with realistic amounts of human influence on the climate and one with minimal human influence - found that the extreme summer temperatures during the 2017 B.C. forest fire season were made more than 20 times more likely by human-induced climate change.

RELATED: B.C. Wildfires 2018: Province calls for federal aid

Researchers found that the extreme high temperatures combined with dry conditions increase the likelihood of wildfire ignition and spread.

The 1.2 million hectares burned in 2017 set a record - only to be surpassed in 2018. Through their research, the scientists concluded that the area burned was seven to 11 times larger than would have been expected without human influences on the climate. The scientists also found this is a trend that is likely to intensify in the future, without further action.

RELATED: Ignoring climate change poses potential catastrophe for B.C.

According to Environment and Climate Change Canada, the extreme 2017 forest fire season in B.C. caused 65,000 people to be displaced from their homes, and millions to be exposed to smoke-filled air harmful to human health.

"As the climate continues to warm, we can expect that costly extreme wildfire seasons - like 2017 in B.C. - will become more likely in the future. This will have increasing impacts on many sectors, including forest management, public health, and infrastructure," said Megan Kirchmeier-Young, research scientist, Environment and Climate Change Canada.

urn:contentItem:5SFJ-FMM1-JDH3-G1G7-00000-00UPDATED: Helicopter crash sparked wildfire north of Pitt Lake2018-05-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:55:07ZLexisNexisNEWSUPDATED: Helicopter crash sparked wildfire north of Pitt Lake

The five hectare forest fire that broke out north of Pitt Lake on Sunday was caused by a helicopter missing its landing.

According to the Transportation Safety Board, one pilot and one passenger were on board the Eurocopter AS355 when it took off from Langley midday Sunday and flew towards Pitt Lake before crashing at about 2:15 p.m.

"The aircraft was landing on a forestry road and as the aircraft was touching down, the pilot lost control," a spokesperson said.

"The rotor blades contacted the ground and the aircraft rolled onto its side."

Both the pilot and passenger suffered minor injuries but the helicopter was "substantially damaged."

The forest fire, which has more than doubled in size since Sunday, is about eight kilometres north of Pitt Lake and near the Upper Pitt river hatchery.

BC Wildfire said that the fire is proving hard to fight, with high winds expected and accessible only by air and water and no structures are at risk.

"It's basically burning in timber of a steep hillside," said fire information officer Jeanne Larson.

"But there's nothing there, no infrastructure."

Currently, BC Wildfire has dispatched a three-person initial attack crew, two fallers, a 10 person fire suppression crew and two helicopters to the site.

(CP) - Campers spending a final summer weekend in the woods in the southern part of the province are being asked to stick close to lakes because of extreme forest fire conditions.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Conditions across the province are tinder dry and fire officials want to make sure they can get people out of an area if other fires break out, said Wendy Stewart, spokeswoman for the B.C. forest service.</p><p nitf:lede="true">-BODY- "We are issuing a somewhat unusual warning to folks that if they are in the woods. . . to stay in highly visible areas near roads and areas where there is lots of water such as lakes,'' said Stewart.</p><p>"We are concerned that if a fire breaks out, it could move very aggressively and endanger folks who are using the woods. We want to be able to, if we need to, to get in and get them out safely.''</p><p>Fire officials have put 650 residents of Princeton, a small Okanagan town, on evacuation alert because of concerns that predicted strong, gusty winds could push a raging forest fire closer to their town,</p><p>The fire near Tulameen, northwest of Princeton, broke out Monday and had grown to 26 square kilometres by the weekend.</p><p>Fire officials beefed up resources Thursday and Friday after weather reports predicted gusty winds which could push the fire closer to the small town.</p><p>"It's been on the absolute tear ever since it broke out. The winds through the area continue to buffet it and it's moving very aggressively through the timber.''</p><p>Residents can be asked to leave their homes with 10 minutes notice.</p><p>"We're very hopeful that there will not be any property losses, but when you have this big a fire that is behaving very erratically and very aggressively, it's very hard to contain it,'' said Stewart.</p><p>Two ranches closest to the fire have already been evacuated and farmers are relocating their stock.</p><p>There is a province-wide ban on campfires.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier (CP) _ Several residents evacuated because of a raging forest fire in Pictou County were allowed to return home Sunday.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The fire, which burned about five hectares of woods Saturday, is now under control but could flare up again depending on the weather, said fire officials.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>Residents were asked to leave their homes Saturday night as a precautionary measure.</p><p>There were no open flames but the fire was still burning below the ground on Sunday. About 20 hectares of forest and marshland were destroyed.</p><p> I think it was raining in some spots,'' said Terry Moore, fire duty officer for the provincial Natural Resources Department in Shubenacadie.</p><p> So hopefully that will take care of whatever is left and keep us going for another few days.''</p><p>Fire officials said the late spate of forest fires were fuelled by dry conditions and strong winds.</p><p>(Halifax Chronicle-Herald)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier "We've had a fairly active spring.</p><p>Similarly, dry conditions, hot sun and wind persist in Northern Ontario, where as of Sunday about 23 fires were burning.</p><p>Nova Scotia, Prince Edward Island and Newfoundland have also experienced unusually high forest fire activity this spring.</p><p>Nova Scotia has been hit with two major blazes, one in the Shag Harbour area and the other in Welshtown, leading to the evacuation of about 1,100 people. The Shag Harbour fire destroyed a house, a mobile home and several sheds and hunting camps.</p><p>Last year, 338 fires burned 400 hectares of land in Nova Scotia over the entire forest fire season. Twice as much property has been destroyed so far this year.</p><p>"We had very little snow this winter,'' said John Whidden, communications officer for the Nova Scotia Department of Natural Resources.</p><p>Prince Edward Island experienced a small rash of fires early last week, but rain over much of the province brought some relief.</p><p>There was also concern in Newfoundland, where roughly 40 fires were reported last week.</p><p>In contrast, British Columbia, Alberta and Saskatchewan have all experienced a quiet spring. Last year was one of the worst forest fire years on record for B.C. and Alberta.</p><p>"What a difference a year makes,'' said Wendy Stewart, B.C. provincial fire information officer.</p><p>"Last year at this time there were 325 fires burning. This year there are 1,000. We've had an extraordinary mix of weather over the last 18 months.''</p><p>In eastern Manitoba, four communities were hit hard in the first week of May and about 1,000 people registered as evacuees with the ManitobaRed Cross. They have since returned home.</p><p>Eight homes were lost in the community of St. Theresa Point in the northeast part of the province.</p><p>Cooler temperatures last week provided some relief, and the fires have now been brought under control.</p><p>At the same time, a restricted fire zone remained in effect for the northern portion of Ontario's eastern fire region. It extends east of Marathon to the Quebec border and north of the French and Mattawa Rivers, including Manitoulin Island.</p><p>On Saturday, there were four new fires reported in Ontario, three in Wawa and one in Algonquin Park.</p><p>A fire reported Thursday in the Northern Ontario town of Chapleau was of particular concern to firefighters, who continued to battle the blaze on the weekend. About 4,500 people live in the town and surrounding area.</p><p>Warm weather is forecast for this week, raising fears the fire could spread.</p><p>Johnston said despite the early start to the year's forest fire season, future activity is difficult to predict because of uncertain weather patterns.</p><p>"Forecasting forest fires is pretty crystal-bally.''</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier (AP) _ A fast-moving blaze that began as a grass fire destroyed 15 homes and forced dozens to flee as it spread to about 1,600 hectares before being contained overnight, officials said Friday.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>AP</p></bodyText></section><p>Hot spots remained Friday, and more than 200 homes and businesses lost electricity as the flames consumed utility poles, damaged transformers and burned at least 40 kilometres of power lines. No major injuries were reported.</p><p>The pine forest fire was the state's biggest in 20 years, Natural Resources Secretary Scott Hassett said.</p><p>The blaze in rural Adams County began Thursday when a landowner started a small fire to clear grass before building a campfire, said Steve Courtney, a Natural Resources incident commander.</p><p>Along with the homes, the fire destroyed camper-trailers and other outbuildings, fire chief Dick Meyers said. Gov. Jim Doyle, who surveyed the damage by helicopter, said he saw many houses still standing.</p><p>Nearly 100 people had fled a 260-square-kilometre area, and about two dozen spent the night at an elementary school.</p><p>Jackie Jones, 44, said she had to drive through a "rolling ball of fire'' to escape and saw ashes falling from the sky like snow.</p><p>"God bless us, we're here. We lost probably everything,'' she said.</p><p>Some people reported seeing flames shooting about 35 metres into the air, said Trent Marty, head of the state's forest protection bureau.</p><p>After his helicopter tour, the governor met with families evacuated from the area, near where a tornado killed two people and destroyed homes in 1994.</p><p>"They are all very anxious right now to get back in there and see what happened,'' he said.</p><p>Jeanne Surlaski, 53, wiped away tears after learning Friday that her house had been spared, as it was during the tornado 11 years ago. "I was lucky again,'' she said.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5VPJ-NF51-JDH1-C4C8-00000-00Arts and Culture: Contemporary circus shows off for hometown crowd2019-03-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:55:07ZLexisNexisWHATSONPg. 0Arts and Culture: Contemporary circus shows off for hometown crowd

For an adventurous outing on the first Sunday in spring, what could be better than an afternoon with some world-class buskers and circus performers?

Articus Productions is presenting a "circus variety show" called Forest/Fire starting at 2 p.m. under the enormous rafters of the 40,000-square-foot Lot 42 Factory Space on Ardelt Drive in Kitchener.

The talent is world class, but also hometown: This is an opportunity for us to welcome, and to get to know, a new addition to the regional arts community.

Articus is a performance company that specializes in "fusing theatre with circus and aerial arts." It has operated out of Toronto, then Muskoka, and now here: After some time in Waterloo, last fall the Lot 42 Factory Space became its home base.

I dropped by there this week to meet the proprietors, Lindsay Bellaire and Phillip Psutka.

The setup is impressive in its size and its simplicity: a set of ropes, silks and hoops suspended from the heights of the massive overhead crane permanently installed in the former steel plant, with a few props scattered about, mainly juggling pins and balls.

This is where they create and develop touring stage productions, busking shows, as well as aerial and ground acts for corporate events, weddings, and private parties.

It is also where Bellaire and Psutka operate a circus school that offers aerial classes for children as young as eight and adults, as well as training for professional performers.

Both began their artistic education and training at the University of Windsor School of Dramatic Art.

The aim, in all these endeavours, is "to deliver surprising, exciting and empowering experiences that lift the human spirit and redefine possible by bringing the extraordinary into the lives of their students and audiences."

At this point, the goal is simply, as Bellaire puts it, "to establish a presence" in their adopted community. To that end, on Sunday they'll be presenting their "Lumberjack Show," which they've toured many times.

For this piece, the drama is centred around a "lumberjack challenge" event, where a character named Jill is tested "through a series of entertaining, often hilarious, and sometimes dangerous challenges to become the first-ever female lumberjack."

The publicity materials promise "comedy, axe juggling, gigantic muscles ... daring aerial rope feats" and various "additional surprises."

Forest/Fire opens with an aerial clown act called "Chesh's Tale," which is loosely based on the Cheshire Cat from "Alice in Wonderland."

The artist here is Toronto-based Emily Hughes, who will tell the story of how Chesh "discovers parts of herself she never knew existed" as she is "brought to life on suspended fabric."

After a brief intermission, the show will conclude with a third act: "The FireGuy Show" by Fire Guy, a.k.a. Brant Matthews.

Matthews, also based in Toronto, is a seasoned performer who specializes in fire juggling, fire eating and fire breathing.

Among Fire Guy's many accomplishments is becoming, last August, the Guinness world record holder for "eating" the most fire torches in one minute - 101, to be exact.

If you go, on your way in, during intermission and after the show, you'll also see aerial performances by local artists Andrea Milne and Nicole Smith, and roaming performances by up-and-coming buskers from in and around the region. What you won't see are animals.

urn:contentItem:7VWF-3JX0-Y9NS-W3BB-00000-00Forest fire near Lillooet, B.C., growing despite firefighting efforts2009-06-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:55:07ZLexisNexisGENERAL AND NATIONAL NEWSForest fire near Lillooet, B.C., growing despite firefighting effortsCP

LILLOOET, B.C. _ A massive forest fire that continued to burn Sunday in British Columbia's Interior had doubled in size in just two days, prompting officials to ask for even more resources to battle the blaze.

The fire near Tyaughton Lake, west of the community of Lillooet, had doubled in size since Friday, growing to more than 4,000 hectares, said fire information officer Mary Anne Leach.

''That's due to some pretty aggressive fire behaviour (Saturday) afternoon and overnight,'' said Leach.

Leach said there were 200 firefighters and 11 helicopters battling the blaze, and officials had requested even more resources, particularly additional helicopters.

''We're hitting it as hard as we can,'' said Leach. ''That's a huge number of resources on a fire like this.''

Leach said the fire had been growing as strong winds fuelled the flames _ and she said those winds could posed similar problems on Sunday.

The fire, which was discovered on May 29, is believed to have been caused by people, and officials were investigating precisely how it started.

Some residents who were ordered to leave their homes have since been allowed to returns, but several areas remained under evacuation orders.

The orders were in effect in Marshall Lake, Liza Lake, Carol Lake, Mud Creek, Tyaughton Lake and Gun Creek Road.

Three other communities _ Gun Lake, Gold Bridge and Bralorne _ were on evacuation alert.

Officials have said several people under evacuation orders had chose not to leave.

The RCMP issued a statement on Sunday stressing that evacuation orders are mandatory and that officers would be enforcing the orders and restricting access to those areas.

The Mounties say officers will enforce road and bridge closures to prevent people from returning to their homes until the orders are lifted.

The release says violating the evacuation orders is illegal and hampers efforts by diverting resources away from battling the blaze and preventing helicopters from dropping flame retardant on areas where people might be.

In addition, the release says emergency crews won't be deployed to rescue anyone who runs into trouble in an area that is subject to an evacuation order.

There are more than a dozen fires bigger than 10 hectares burning across B.C., according to the province's Forests Ministry's website.

The largest is in northern B.C., where a fire at the junction of the Liard and Smith rivers had grown to more than 16,000 hectares.

There were nearly 100 firefighters and five helicopters at work fighting that fire, and 60 people were under an evacuation alert.

urn:contentItem:7VVJ-D0H0-Y9NS-W05X-00000-00B.C. heat wave setting records, worsening forest fire threat2009-06-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:55:07ZLexisNexisWESTERN GENERAL NEWSB.C. heat wave setting records, worsening forest fire threatCP

VANCOUVER _ Much of B.C. is baking in record temperatures that are heating up the forest fire situation and triggering burning bans in many regions of the province.

Temperature records were shattered Tuesday in several cities, including Victoria, where the thermometer reached 30.4 degrees, breaking the old record of 27.3 degrees set 31 years ago.

Records were also set in Squamish, where it was 33 degrees, White Rock and Pitt Meadows and more records could fall as the heat wave continues.

''We are definitely seeing warm, dry conditions throughout pretty much the entire province right now and this is increasing the risk of fire starts and the risk that those fires can spread quickly,'' said Kim Steinbart, provincial fire information officer for the B.C. Wildfire Management branch.

Fire service officials said hot, dry conditions were expected to last until at least Friday.

Steinbart said there have been about 390 fires since fire season began April 1, burning more than 7,000 hectares.

It's actually an average number, she said, but this year there have been several fires that have threatened communities in the past month, forcing evacuations.

The main priority for provincial fire crews for now is a wildfire burning west of Lillooet that has scorched 850 hectares of bush and forced the evacuation of about 25 homes and businesses. Another 200 people remained on evacuation alert.

The fire between Gun Lake and Tyaughton Lake has not grown since Tuesday, and is about 15 per cent contained, Steinbart said.

There were 100 firefighters, nine helicopters and heavy equipment tackling the blaze.

Elise Riedlinger, fire information officer for the Kamloops Fire Centre, said the focus for fire crews in and around Tyaughton is on protecting structures and property. So far, none have been damaged and the fire is up to 15 per cent contained.

''The weather continues to pose some challenges for the crews,'' she said. ''We're seeing very hot and dry temperatures and we're also seeing inversions, which are creating very smoky and hard-to-see conditions.''

Smoke from the Tyaughton fire forced Metro Vancouver to issue an air quality advisory for the Fraser Valley on Wednesday.

Another fire near the Yukon border, 220 kilometres west of Fort Nelson, has forced the closure of the Alaska Highway on and off, and travellers are advised to check for closures.

The fire threat is high to extreme over most of Vancouver Island, and relatively high throughout most of central and southern British Columbia.

Burning bans have been put in place in several regions.

urn:contentItem:7W9S-K420-Y9NS-W3SF-00000-00Spain's La Palma island forest fire under control; 15-day blaze in Catalonia extinguished2009-08-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:55:07ZLexisNexisFOREIGN GENERAL NEWSSpain's La Palma island forest fire under control; 15-day blaze in Catalonia extinguishedCIARAN GILESCP

MADRID _ A forest fire on the Canary Island of La Palma was brought under control Tuesday and another that raged for two weeks in Spain's northern Catalonia region has been extinguished, an emergency official said.

The La Palma fire, which started last Friday in the southern part of the island, destroyed some 3,000 hectares (7,400 acres) and burned some 50 houses. La Palma is one of the least developed and greenest of the seven Canary Islands off northwest Africa, and was celebrated by pop star Madonna in her song ''La Isla Bonita.''

''There are no prospects of the fire (on La Palma) spreading. It's now in a controlled area and all that is left to do is put it out,'' said island security official Jose Miguel Ruano.

La Palma is also home to some of the world's most powerful observatories, including the recently opened C130 million ($185 million) Gran Telescopio Canarias reflecting mirror telescope atop an extinct volcano. The telescope's location above cloud cover was selected to take advantage of La Palma's normally pristine skies.

The fire forced some 4,000 people to be temporarily evacuated from southeastern towns Saturday. Most have returned to their homes, some of which have been gutted by flames.

Ruano said the cause of the fire was still being investigated but said it may have been started by a firework rocket.

On the mainland, the northeastern regional government of Catalonia said a blaze that led to the deaths of five firefighters in a nature reserve near the town of Horta de Sant Joan, west of Barcelona, has finally been put out after 15 days.

That blaze had destroyed 1,140 hectares (2,800 acres) of woodland.

Wildfires have killed at least nine people and burned about 75,000 hectares (185,000 acres) of forest and scrubland in Spain so far this year, more than double the amount burnt in all of 2008.

Firefighters battling a huge forest fire in the Sierra Nevada will face increasingly difficult conditions this week as a heat wave sets in.

Officials say the Ferguson Fire has scorched nearly 53 square miles (137 square kilometres) of timber and brush west of Yosemite National Park, and 13 per cent of its perimeter is contained Monday morning.

The National Weather Service says a widespread heat advisory including the fire area will be in effect Tuesday afternoon through Thursday evening for high temperatures ranging from 103 to 108 degrees (39.4 to 42.2 Celsius).

More than 3,000 firefighters are battling the fire, which broke out July 13. One firefighter died the following day and six others have been injured.

Thirteen areas are under mandatory evacuation orders.

urn:contentItem:5WGW-WH21-JDH1-C4SB-00000-00First Nation community evacuated due to fire2019-07-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:55:07ZLexisNexisCANADA / WORLDPg. A7First Nation community evacuated due to fireColin Perkel The Canadian Press

A raging forest fire in northwestern Ontario has prompted the full evacuation of the First Nation community of Keewaywin, authorities said on Thursday.

More than 200 residents considered vulnerable had already been flown this week to Sioux Lookout, Ont., as the fire moved closer, while roughly 200 more were being sent to another city Thursday.

Joe Meekis, a former longtime chief of Keewaywin - which has about 450 residents - called the situation scary.

"The community is threatened," Meekis said in an interview from Sioux Lookout. "Everybody has to get out."

Known as Red Lake Fire Number 23, the blaze is now about 546 square kilometres. It began as a small fire a week ago about 40 kilometres from the community. Earlier this week, the winds picked up and it "grew really fast," Meekis said.

Smoke began drifting into the community, prompting residents to close windows and doors, and shut down air conditioners.

Ultimately, the chief declared an emergency, and the initial transfer of babies, pregnant women and children under five and their families began. On Tuesday and Wednesday, a total of 227 people were flown about 330 kilometres south to Sioux Lookout, which has declared its own state of emergency aimed at defraying the cost of helping the arrivals.

Volunteers in the town were helping provide access to snacks, supplies and information, as well as responding to requests from the evacuees, a spokesperson said.

"All evacuees are being housed at a local hotel, and a local restaurant is providing all of the meals," said Brian MacKinnon, the town's manager of corporate services.

"(However), Sioux Lookout is presently at capacity with respect to the number of evacuees we can host."

As a result, the remaining evacuees, numbering more than 200, were being flown to Timmins, Ont., on Thursday, leaving just a skeleton crew in the community for security purposes, Meekis said.

"They're moving people today, as we speak," Meekis said.

By noon Thursday, the fire was 10 kilometres southwest of the Keewaywin boundary, which is 12 kilometres from the town itself, according to the provincial Ministry of Natural Resources.

Jonathan Scott, an information officer with Aviation, Forest Fire and Emergency Services, said an incident management team was on site looking for "aerial ignition opportunities" in which fires are deliberately set to take the blaze to natural barriers and slow its spread. Crews and equipment were also in the area.

In all, more than two dozen fires are burning in northwestern Ontario, 12 out of control.

Even the village nursing station is divided in two, with Inuit patients on one side of the building and Cree on the other.</p><p>-BODY- Monday, however, the two solitudes of this remote post on the southeast shore of Hudson Bay worked together to evacuate their village in the face of an advancing forest fire.</p><p>They climbed on board Armed Forces Hercules transports and Hydro Quebec aircraft flown up from southern Quebec. Local leaders, however, were careful to load equal numbers of Cree and Inuit on departing planes, for fear of upsetting either side.</p><p>"They didn't want to take out one community first, they did it equally,'' said Rev. Tom Martin, reached by telephone Monday.</p><p>Forest fires are unheard of on the treeless tundra of Arctic Quebec, but Great Whale River sits on the northern reaches of the tree line, 1,200 kilometres north of Montreal.</p><p>On Sunday afternoon, after weeks of dry weather, a cooking fire at a Cree hunting camp ignited a five-kilometre-wide blaze that within hours was threatening to jump the river that skirts the southern edge of the village.</p><p>By 5 p.m., Cree and Inuit leaders declared a state of emergency and decided to call in military aircraft from Trenton, Ont., to airlift the community's 1,500 residents.</p><p>Six aircraft, including a plane from Air Inuit, flew through the night from the community's gravel runway, ferrying the sick, the young and the elderly to the safety of La Grande, Que.</p><p>By 7 a.m. Monday, with 250 residents removed, early morning thunderstorms had dampened the fire and evacuation plans were put on hold.</p><p>The fire was reduced to smouldering hot spots by Monday night. (National Post)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4SW1-JFB0-TX4V-K05G-00000-00Arson ruled out but charges still expected to be laid in N.S. forest fire2008-06-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:55:07ZLexisNexisATLANTIC REGIONAL NEWSArson ruled out but charges still expected to be laid in N.S. forest fireCP

HALIFAX _ Charges are pending in a forest fire that forced the evacuation of thousands of people from their homes outside Halifax two weeks ago and destroyed two houses.

The Nova Scotia Department of Natural Resources is planning to lay the charges under the province's Forestry Act.

Spokesman Tim Conrad said Saturday that the RCMP is not involved since the blaze isn't considered arson, but fire investigators have determined it was man-made.

Conrad said the department isn't disclosing who, or how many people, are facing charges, or the nature of the charges ,since that could jeopardize their investigation.

Conrad confirmed the charges carry a penalty of a $500 fine, or six months in jail, or both.

It's a violation of the Forestry Act to set a fire without a permit in or near the woods during Nova Scotia's fire season, which runs from April to October.

Conrad said the department has identified the origin of the fire, but isn't releasing any details on the location or cause.

There were reports at the time that the fire started in a wooded area that people often used for partying.

Another fire that was burning at the same time outside Tantallon, N.S., has also been determined to have been man-made, but so far no charges are pending in that fire.

Conrad said the origin of the Tantallon fire has been identified, and investigators are asking anyone with information about the cause of the blaze to contact their local Department of Natural Resources office.

(CP) _ A forest fire northwest of Kenora, Ont., continued to grow Wednesday and more residents were evacuated from a cottage area threatened by the blaze.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>The fire near Catherine Lake was burning out of control about 15 kilometres from nearby Minaki, Ont., forcing the continued closure of a highway. Today, other than smoke in the valley, all appears<br/>quiet. On the edge of the nearby mountains, however, today's attack is being<br/>planned.</p><p>UNIDENTIFIED MAN: Our whole flank on this side that we've worked so hard<br/>at for the last eight days is going to get tested, and we'll see how good we did.<br/>Don't let your guard down now. Pay attention to our surroundings. It's still just<br/>as dangerous out there as it was when we started.</p><p>CHISHOLM: For Paul Pasutto and a crew of eight civilian firefighters, this is<br/>week two. Paul's brother, Rick, lives nearby, and when the call for help went<br/>out, Rick's brothers and friends pitched in.</p><p>PAUL PASUTTO [Business Consultant - Firefighter]: We're hooking up with<br/>guys that know exactly what they're doing. But after a day or two up here, you<br/>start to get the hang of the dangers, and keep your head up and just make sure<br/>everybody's communicating well.</p><p>CHISHOLM: The volunteer crew proved so effective, the BC Forest Service<br/>hired them. Dropping their loads metres from where the<br/>firefighters are working. James Scramstad is a Kelowna dentist and a member<br/>of the team. A week ago, he got the call and gave up his dental tools for a fire<br/>hose.</p><p>JAMES SCRAMSTAD [Dentist - Firefighter]: Definitely a hot environment, but<br/>definitely a bit more exciting than being in the dental chair.</p><p>CHISHOLM: This fire is now in steep terrain on the edge of the Kettle Valley<br/>rail line. All the firefighters and equipment are amassed here, trying to keep the<br/>fire here from jumping the line, because if it does, there are no access roads<br/>above here, and the fire will become almost impossible to fight.</p><p>PASUTTO: Chris just said it's burning right up to the ridge. So, I think we've<br/>got to go down and nip that one first. He also told me there's no roads going<br/>up. Quebec and the Atlantic provinces endured fires too.</p><p>Mercifully, officials say, it's drawing to a close.</p><p>"We're not getting the hellacious kinds of conditions we saw in June," said David Hahn, a Northwest Territories fire official.</p><p>'Two brutal months saw thousands of residents across the country flee their isolated communities amid smoke or advancing flame.</p><p>But the heat has finally abated in most parts of Alberta, Saskatchewan and Manitoba. All three provinces had for weeks faced thunderstorms that brought lightning, but little moisture.</p><p>More than 3,000 firefighters battled hundreds of blazes across the province in June. Now, fewer than 100 are patrolling 22 fires in an area about 350 kilometres north of Saskatoon.</p><p>The province has spent $77 million this year fighting fires which have claimed more than 14,000 square kilometres of forest.</p><p>In Alberta, which lost 3,400 square kilometres, only one fire was burning Wednesday. In B.C., a relatively mild season has claimed only 460 square kilometres of forest.</p><p>Ontario -- where nearly 5,000 square kilometres have been scarred by almost 1,500 fires since April 1 -- was heating up again Wednesday as dry weather sent the fire hazard back to extreme.</p><p>Ontario has weighed in with the heftiest firefighting tab, an estimated $84 million.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier KELOWNA, B.C. (CP) _ Rain showers have done little to douse the threat of forest fires in British Columbia's Okanagan Valley.

A month-long stretch of hot, dry weather _ including a record-breaking 34.1 degrees at the Kelowna airport on Saturday _ has scorched the valley bottom and heightened fears of a busy wildfire season.

Environment Canada says the Central Okanagan had just 41 millimetres of precipitation from March to May this year, less than half the normal precipitation of 87 millimetres in that period.

In contrast, 80 millimetres fell during the same three-month period in 2003 _ the year a massive forest fire destroyed 239 houses on the southern fringes of Kelowna.

But Dale Bojahra of the B.C. Forest Service in Penticton said Monday that residents don't need to start watering their roofs just yet.

''We should have a normal summer if we get rain once a week for several weeks,'' he said. ''It's never a single weather event that determines a fire season.''

As an example, Bojahra said, the dry spring of 2004 had many Okanagan residents worried they'd see a sequel to the Okanagan Mountain Park fire. It ended up being a slow fire season because there was enough rainfall that summer.

Still, indicators this year are disquieting. Craig Beeson of the B.C. Environment Ministry's water stewardship division said ''the snowpack in the Okanagan has been just below normal for the last few months.''

The greater the winter snowpack, the more moisture is absorbed into the ground.

During a Restricted Fire Zone, the use of open fires - such as campfires, or burning of brush or debris is restricted. Failure to comply could result in fines of up to $25,000 and three months in jail, as well as financial responsibility for the costs incurred in fighting a forest fire.

Portable gas or propane stoves are permitted for use for cooking or warmth, though they should be closely monitored. Portable charcoal barbecues and Hibachis are not permitted unless within 100 metres of a dwelling, or within an organized campground.

Commercial campground operators may allow their guests to enjoy campfires during a Restricted Fire Zone period provided they meet certain conditions in the Outdoor Fires Regulation (207/96).

THESSALONIKI, Greece - A large forest fire that broke out at a remote monastic community where women have not been allowed for a thousand years spread Thursday to a nearby resort area, forcing the evacuation of a seaside vacation village and sending up a thick pall of smoke over the area.

It was not clear how the fire started Wednesday on the Mount Athos peninsula, a World Heritage site and self-ruled community of Orthodox monks that bans women - and even female animals - from entering. There were no immediate reports of damage to the northern Greek peninsula's 20 medieval monasteries, which visitors can only access by sea.

Firefighters managed to prevent the flames from sweeping through Ouranoupolis, a resort village north of the peninsula, on Thursday, although the fire damaged outlying building and elderly people and others were taken to a nearby beach as a precaution. The fire brigade said in a statement that 110 firefighters, assisted by water trucks, five water-dropping aircraft and two helicopters were trying to contain the blaze.

The fire brigade did not have an estimate of the extent of the burned area.

Greece is in the grips of a heat wave, and wildfires have been burning around the country. In the southern Peloponnese area, firefighters were trying to extinguish two big fires in the areas of Tripoli and Corinth that broke out on Tuesday and destroyed thousands of acres of forest and scrub. Officials said no inhabited areas were under threat, and the blazes seemed to be on the wane Thursday.

A 45-year-old Greek man was arrested and charged with accidentally starting the one fire, in the Tripoli area, which has been declared in a state of emergency.

Forest fires are common during Greece's typically long, hot summers. In 2007, more than 60 people died in a series of huge blazes in the Peloponnese and central Greece.

It uses factors such as the relative humidity, temperature, previous 24-hour rain amount, wind directions and wind speed in combination with the forest fuel type and loads to determine the risk of the forest to certain fire types. From this calculation the Forest Fire Danger Rating is made in consultation with the fire chiefs of the six area municipalities and the Ministry of Natural Resources.

urn:contentItem:5W89-8HM1-JBVR-32PR-00000-00Wildfire near Pikangikum First Nation slowing its spread: officials2019-06-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:55:07ZLexisNexisWEATHER,ONTARIOWildfire near Pikangikum First Nation slowing its spread: officialsWildfire near Pikangikum slowing its spread: officialsLiam CaseyThe Canadian Press

A wildfire that has forced about 2,000 people from their homes in northwestern Ontario has begun to slow its spread, officials said Monday.

The forest fire near Pikangikum First Nation started on Wednesday and by Saturday it had grown to 36 square kilometres. A spokeswoman for the Ministry of Resources and Forestry said that on Monday it covered 38 square kilometres.

"The fire has slowed growing, but obviously it's still something our guys are trying to get under control," Jolanta Kowalski said. "It is being attacked hard."

Kowalski said fire crews are bracing for a change in winds.

Environment Canada issued a special air quality statement Monday that the winds could sweep the smoke from Red Lake 14, as it's officially known, into the nearby First Nation.

"Smoke plumes from a forest fire east of Pikangikum have resulted in deteriorated air quality in the area," the agency said in its statement.

"Individuals may experience symptoms such as increased coughing, throat irritation, headaches or shortness of breath. Children, seniors and those with cardiovascular or lung disease, such as asthma, are especially at risk."

Nishnawbe Aski Nation, which represents 49 First Nation communities across northern Ontario, said about 2,000 people have been evacuated from the fly-in community, located about 500 kilometres northwest of Thunder Bay, Ont., to other cities in Ontario and Manitoba.

The fire has damaged the broadband communications in the area, Nishnawbe Aski Nation said in a statement, knocking out phone and internet service.

"Bell technicians have been allowed to assess the damage in the community but due to weather delays they will not be able to fly into Pikangikum until Tuesday," Nishnawbe Aski Nation said.

Kowalski said crews are also busy creating a "combustible-free zone" - a lengthy mound of dirt - with bulldozers on the north side of the blaze "so the fire can't jump it."

Evacuations continued Monday. The province said all vulnerable people have been transported out of the area.

"At this moment in time, the people who remain in the community are people who don't want to leave and that lines up with the fact there is no anticipated imminent danger," said Indigenous Affairs Minister Greg Rickford.

"The fire is managed, but this is always about the smoke and there may be some change in wind direction in the next day or two."

He said the province remains on guard to evacuate the First Nation completely should the chief make that decision.

urn:contentItem:4700-NW10-01G6-84S2-00000-00<published>1998-04-22T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:55:07Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NATIONAL GENERAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>AM-Dry-Prairies, Bgt ; CGY OUT CQQ; Budget; Prairies bracing for bad forest fire season</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>CALGARY</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>CALGARY (CP) - Hot sunny days with clear blue skies are not the forecasts that forest fire officials on the Prairies want to hear these days.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Alberta is bracing for what could be the worst forest-fire season in decades after a dry, warm winter.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The situation is critical in northern Manitoba, and conditions are dry in Saskatchewan as well.</p><p>"We are very concerned about the possibility of a bad fire spring,'' said Ty Lund, Alberta Environment Minister.</p><p>Earlier this week strong winds whipped up flames that destroyed more than 80 hectares of land near DeWinton, 40 kilometres south of Calgary.</p><p>There were no injuries, but at its peak the blaze travelled within 100 metres of at least two homes and some barns.</p><p>"I was really worried,'' Cec Papke, one of several residents who battled smoke and flames with rakes and shovels, said as the fire was doused a short distance from his home.</p><p>"I had a vision of the paddocks and the hay going. When I got here it was all smoke, and flames were licking and going like hell,'' he said.</p><p>The unusual winter bears a disturbing resemblance to conditions that preceded huge forest fires in the early 1980s.</p><p>"People who have been in the business for a long time talk about back in the early '80s and how this past winter has been so similar to some of those years,'' Lund said.</p><p>"We are gearing up.''</p><p>More than 1.3 million hectares of Alberta trees were destroyed in 1981 - the worst forest fire year of the 1980s.</p><p>Most of the fires occurred in the north - the result of lightning strikes in tinder-dry forests.</p><p>The average yearly land loss to forest fires in Alberta is 15,000 hectares, but 1995 was especially bad when 340,000 hectares were destroyed. By comparison, 1997 was a mild year with only 4,724 hectares lost.</p><p>As of April 21, there had been 63 grass and bush blazes this year, said Kelly O'Shea with the Environment Department. That's more than three times the number in the same period last year.</p><p>Forest fires will begin breaking out when treed areas dry up as well, said O'Shea.</p><p>Rain is desperately needed, agrees John Cook of Saskatchewan's provincial forest fire centre in Prince Albert.</p><p>"We need precipitation of some kind in every place,'' he said.</p><p>It's especially dry in west-central Saskatchewan, where two huge grass fires have been burning for several days. So far this year the province has had 20 fires.</p><p>Surface material - pine needles, leaves and grass - is extremely dry and the forest is at high risk until it greens up, Cook said. Burning permits are required for anyone within four kilometres of a provincial park.</p><p>The unusually dry conditions are being attributed to El Nino - the nickname for the overheating of the equatorial Pacific, an event that occurs every four to seven years and causes havoc with the world's weather.</p><p>While the El Nino phenomenon usually peters out in March, followed by a wetter than normal spring and summer, weather forecasters say this year's El Nino has been so strong that dry conditions could persist well into July. urn:contentItem:5CRR-9MW1-JDV5-F480-00000-00Ontario island set on fire by Parks Canada2014-07-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:55:07ZLexisNexisCANADA / WORLDPg. A8Ontario island set on fire by Parks CanadaControlled forest fire meant to help rare pitch pine trees, which are shade intolerant, flourishDiana Mehta The Canadian Press

Starting a forest fire on an island in the middle of the summer is not something people associate with Parks Canada, but that's exactly what the federal agency had been carefully planning for years.

Finally, with the weather conditions just right, fire crews descended on one of Ontario's Thousand Islands on Tuesday to set fire to part of the land mass - all in the hopes that a rare, fire-dependent pine tree would rise from the ashes.

"We've been waiting a few years to finish this one off," said Katie Ellsworth, fire management co-ordinator with the Thousand Islands National Park, noting that the plan to set a portion of Camelot Island ablaze was first conceived in 2009. "This year, we finally got the window."

The target of the "prescribed fire" was the pitch pine, a tree that can resprout even after its main trunk is burnt in a fire.

In Canada, the tree is found in eastern Ontario along the St. Lawrence River, which winds its way through the Thousand Islands, and in some parts of southern Quebec.

While the pitch pine historically was able to flourish with the help of fires sparked through lightning strikes and traditionally by First Nations people, fire suppression has put it at a disadvantage.

"They're very shade intolerant," explained park superintendent Jeff Leggo, who accompanied reporters on a tour of the island as the fire crackled its way over the terrain's woody undergrowth. "The objective is to sort of level the playing field as far as competition for light goes. The other one is to burn up the duff layer - the organic layer that's on the forest floor - so that seeds can be accepted into mineral soil."

The pitch pine is also of particular significance to the park, which sits on the Canada-U.S. border, some 300 kilometres east of Toronto.

"They're very representative of the area," Leggo said. "They're certainly an important part of the Thousand Islands ecosystem."

Tuesday's efforts, which sent up billowing plumes of grey smoke above Camelot Island, were only given the go-ahead late last week when park staff realized the ideal conditions - or "prescription window"- was approaching.

"On Friday, it was a go," explained Leggo. "These things come up pretty quickly and it's the sort of management action you kind of have to drop whatever you're doing for."

Waiting for the perfect time to carry out the prescribed fire was important because a blaze too strong or too weak would ruin the pitch pine's chances of flourishing.

urn:contentItem:5SXB-KRF1-JDH3-G4KB-00000-00Long history of fire prevention in the Parry Sound region2018-07-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:55:07ZLexisNexisOPINIONPg. 1Long history of fire prevention in the Parry Sound region

PARRY SOUND - July was one of the worst months for forest fires in Ontario's history.

To help spread the word on proper fire precautions, we are sharing this cardboard Ontario Department of Lands and Forests poster, dated 1920 to 1972. This worn poster reads, "STOP ... DID YOU PUT YOUR CAMP FIRE OUT" with a man carrying a fawn away from nearby flames.

In Parry Sound, forest fire legislation passed in 1878 proved to be ineffective, as the public remained indifferent toward fire prevention. In 1920, the Department of Lands and Forests was established when the Bureau of Mines separated from of the Department of Lands, Forests and Mines. The department was responsible for creating and administrating regulations for Crown land, forestry, fishing and wildlife protection, including forest fire fighting. Peter McEwen became the first head district forester in 1922 for Parry Sound and Muskoka.

McEwen was responsible for 75 seasonal patrol rangers and creating an effective forest protection system. In 1925, the permit system was instated, and enabled towermen to distinguish between controlled fires and forest fires. The department underwent multiple changes until 1972, when it was reamalgamated with the Department of Mines and Northern Affairs to form the Ministry of Natural Resources.

Forest fires are started by both natural and human causes, with more than half being attributed to human carelessness. While cozying up by the campfire is a wonderful way to spend time with friends and family, please exercise caution and comply with all local fire bans to help protect our forests.

PARRY SOUND - UPDATE: (8:15 a.m. Wednesday, July 25) Key River fire size remains the same.

With high humidity and scattered showers on July 24, the MNRF reported the fire remained "quiet".

"This allowed ground crews to aggressively establish hose lines south and north of Key Harbour on the west side of the fire and north of the Key River on the east side of the fire," said the MNRF release. "As well, lines were established from the northern tip of the fire around the northeast corner."

The fire is expected to remain relatively quiet for the next couple of days.

"However, fire conditions and behaviour can change quickly. Crews continue to monitor weather and fire behaviour closely. Residents will see smoke in the area as crews continue suppression efforts. Values protection have been put in place in Key Harbour, along parts of the south side of Pickerel River and along a portion of the train tracks east of the fire."

A total of eight helicopters worked the fire on July 24.

As of July 24 the fire was at 5,612 hectares and still not under control.

The cause of the fire was originally stated as "human" on the MNR's website but that classification has since been removed, McCool said, to avoid public speculation.

"Because the cause is still unknown at this time and it is under investigation."

(11:59 p.m., Monday, July 23) The Key River forest fire, known as Parry Sound 33, is now covering an area of 5,612 hectares and the restricted fire zone has been expanded to north of Rosseau.

According to the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry Aviation, Forest Fire and Emergency Services, Parry Sound 33 saw aerial fire suppression again on Monday, July 23. CL415s dropped water on the fire which was remapped at 5,612 hectares. Three heavy helicopters bucketed water to reduce the fire's intensity and co-ordinated with ground crews.

On July 21, the MNRF's Parry Sound district recommended that the communities, municipalities and townships within the area ranging from the western and northern borders of French River Provincial Park, east to Highway 69, and as far south as the south shore of the Key River; including all residents and members of the public on both the north and south shores of the French River, and the Pickerel River, as well as Hartley Bay impose a mandatory evacuation of their residents with boat access only.

There is also a recommendation by the MNRF Parry Sound district to impose an evacuation alert to all residents within this area who have road access to their residences or cottages. These residents should be prepared to evacuate pending a change in the fire situation.

In addition, the MNRF's Sudbury district has recommended that all residents along Hartley Bay Road be placed on an evacuation alert, pending changes to the fire situation.

The Ontario Provincial Police (OPP) and Conservation Officers have been on site helping notify the public of the situation, and facilitating this evacuation.

Aviation, Forest Fire and Emergency Services (AFFES) has also been advised by Ontario Parks that the French River Provincial Park is fully closed west of Highway 69/400. All campers have been or are being evacuated. Ontario Parks has also suspended permit sales for the French River Delta and Pickerel River areas and are restricting entry to park users (everything west of Highway 69/400).

Henvey Inlet First Nation declared a state of emergency as a precautionary measure. As of July 22, the community has successfully and safely evacuated all of its community members, who are receiving accommodation and food.

Due to the extreme fire hazard and the large number of wildfires burning, the MNRF has expanded the Restricted Fire Zone to include some areas of the southern region. The new zone includes areas north of the community of Rosseau, northwest to Caramat, over to the Quebec border along Hwy 11 (to north of Abitibi Canyon) and southeast to Renfrew. This includes Algonquin Park, Parry Sound, Lake Superior Provincial Park, the North Shore of Lake Huron, Wawa, and Hearst. To check out more specific boundaries, visit Ontario.ca/forestfire and click on the interactive fire map.

During a Restricted Fire Zone, the use of open fires - such as campfires, or burning of brush or debris, is restricted. Failure to comply could result in fines of up to $25,000 and three months in jail, as well as financial responsibility for the costs incurred in fighting a forest fire.

Portable gas or propane stoves are permitted for use for cooking or warmth, though they should be closely monitored. Portable charcoal barbecues and Hibachis are not permitted unless within 100 metres of a dwelling, or within an organized campground.

Commercial campground operators may allow their guests to enjoy campfires during a Restricted Fire Zone period provided they meet certain conditions.

The Restricted Fire Zone is a temporary measure to reduce the number of new human-caused wildfires as the Aviation Forest Fire and Emergency Services branch of the Ontario MNRF expects the elevated forest fire hazard to continue into the foreseeable future.

By the evening of July 23 there were 55 active forest fires across the northeast. Of these, 21 are not yet under control, 34 are either being held, under control or being observed.

There was only one new start in the region today. Sudbury 92 located near Johnnie Lake in Killarney Provincial Park covers 0.1 of a hectare and is already under control.

Pursuant to the Emergency Area Order signed July 21, 2018, an Implementation Order has been issued by the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry prohibiting access and travel in portions of Parry Sound District where there are public safety hazards as a result of increased fire activity from Parry Sound 33.

The order restricts travel, access and use in an identified area and may be modified regularly to reflect changing fire conditions. This measure has been put in place to ensure public safety while allowing fire personnel to safely and effectively suppress the fires in the identified area.

All travel and use on the French River waterway, Pickerel River (West of Hwy 69/400), Henvey Inlet, Key River basin, and all associated tributaries that access these river systems, including all access from Georgian Bay, and all islands on Georgian Bay within the French River Provincial Park boundaries, Dokis Island system, and Puddick island and all islands north of Henvey Inlet near shore is prohibited.

All access roads west of Hwy 69/400, from Henvey Inlet north to the French River area are closed.

If a member of the public believes that access within the restricted travel area is necessary for nonrecreational purposes, please call to 705-746-4201 to request a travel authorization permit. MNRF will review the request for access based on the rationale provided, local fire activity, and the potential fire risk.
