The fire has swept over gas wells but did not inflict significant damage.</p><p>Huge plumes of smoke billowing high into the air could be seen as far as 140 kilometres away.</p><p>Firefighters received some help from Mother Nature overnight with 2.5 centimetres of fresh snow on the ground and cool temperatures.</p><p>The fire was heading northeast in a slow encroachment, but no nearby communities appear to be threatened by the blaze.</p><p>(Calgary Sun, Calgary Herald)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">CAPRSS-20011018CPCPG7284</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">CAPRSS2001</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:460V-MKV0-01G6-90R6-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">253760</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2020-06-24</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="241"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>The Canadian Press (CP)</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 2001 Press News Limited, All Rights Reserved</copyright><publicationDate day="18" month="10" year="2001"><dateText>October 18, 2001 Thursday</dateText></publicationDate><classification classificationScheme="publicationtype"><classificationItem><className>Newswires & Press Releases</className></classificationItem></classification></publicationInfo><classification classificationScheme="language"><classificationItem><className>ENGLISH</className></classificationItem></classification><classificationGroup classificationScheme="licensor.indexing-terms"><classification classificationScheme="licensor.subject"><classificationItem><className>SOCIAL; It started southwest of town and -- fanned by gusting winds -- travelled northeast, roaring through the Eagle Point subdivision on the north side just outside La Ronge.</p><p>The blaze came right into town, threatening businesses in an industrial area and a bulk fuel depot.</p><p>On Friday, Andrews was philosophical about his family's loss.</p><p>"It's pretty much done, I guess. There's not too much we can do about it except clean it up and start over again," he said.</p><p>"It's the one dog we'd like to find. If we can find the old guy, then things will be great and we can do this."</p><p>La Ronge wasn't the only community hit by forest fires in the last couple of days. About 400 people were evacuated from the northern Manitoba community of Cross Lake when gusting winds pushed flames to within one kilometre of houses.</p><p>And in northeastern Alberta, heavy smoke from forest fires prompted authorities to remove elderly people and young children with breathing difficulties from the community of Janvier.</p><p>Three fires also burned just outside the oilsands city of Fort McMurray in northeastern Alberta, but were not threatening the city.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:4NMC-4S90-TX4V-K2KB-00000-00Mother Nature offers a bit of relief as forest fire burns in Manitoba2007-05-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:55:07ZLexisNexisWESTERN GENERAL NEWSMother Nature offers a bit of relief as forest fire burns in ManitobaCP

WINNIPEG (CP) _ Dozens of Manitoba forest firefighters are battling a stubborn blaze near Vassar, 100 kilometres southeast of Winnipeg.

Three smaller fires joined together over the weekend and are now burning as one fire that covers about 38 square kilometres.

The blaze is located near several small communities, including Vassar and Badger, but none are in immediate danger.

Tom Mirus, the director of Manitoba's forest fire program, says while the fire remains out of control, the weather has helped a bit.

He says cloudy skies, a tiny amount of rain, and high humidity levels have prevented the fire from spreading too quickly.

''They had a sprinkle of rain and that was it,'' Mirus said. ''It's keeping us pretty busy.''

Mirus said crews have been focusing on areas of the fire that are near communities, and are still trying to get the blaze surrounded and contained.

Only people bothered by smoke have left the communities.

The cause of the fire remained a mystery on Monday, and four investigators were working in the area trying to figure out who or what was responsible.

Mirus said conditions are still tinder dry and ripe for more fires as there has been little precipitation since the snow melt.

Spring foliage has yet to bud, meaning there is little shade or greenery to slow the spread of fire through grass, deadfall and garbage.

The forecast called for sun and wind for the rest of the week.

Mirus said that of 35 fire grass and forest fires reported so far this year, all were caused by man. The biggest culprits are ATVs running through the forest, and hot mufflers igniting dry grass.

''Often they don't know they're started a fire,'' Mirus said of ATV riders. ''It's major headache for us.''

(Winnipeg Free Press, Winnipeg Sun)

A1 / FRONT</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo><nitf:fixture xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/">News</nitf:fixture></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Thousands flee B.C. forest fire</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>Steve Mertl</nitf:byline><nitf:dateline>SALMON ARM, B.C.</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">In the largest exodus in B.C. history, about 8,000 people -- half the population of this southern Interior city -- have fled their homes and community.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Spurred by fears that high winds would spread a nearby forest fire, the exodus allowed firefighters to turn their attention to the 5,000-hectare blaze without worrying about a panicked stream of refugees.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"It's a relief for me," city fire chief Ken Tebo said yesterday.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>The Canadian Press</p></bodyText></section><p>B.C. Premier Glen Clark had declared a provincial state of emergency for the city and district late Sunday, giving authorities sweeping powers to order people out.</p><p>However, many residents didn't wait and began leaving after an initial alert was issued Sunday afternoon. By dawn yesterday, officials estimated 80 per cent of residents in the danger zones had left.</p><p>Clark, who stayed to watch the evacuation, called the effort superb and praised residents for co-operating.</p><p>The evacuation was the largest in the province's history, Clark estimates, and would have become "a crisis" if it had to be accomplished quickly.</p><p>The B.C. emergency program announced provincial parks normally used for only daytime visitors could be used as campgrounds by evacuees. Others went to stay with friends and relatives in the area.</p><p>Last week, high winds of up to 90 kilometres per hour sent the fire racing towards town.</p><p>Winds of up to 80 kilometres were originally forecast for yesterday afternoon. But a revised weather forecast said winds were expected to gust to no more than 50 kilometres per hour.</p><p>Fire information officer Mitzi Bushell said that was good news, and meant winds would not come during the hottest, driest part of the day.</p><p>Dangerous embers from the fire's surge last week were landing up to 1.5 kilometres ahead of the blaze, Bushell said. A force of 300 firefighters, 100 soldiers and water-bombing helicopters and planes were fighting the blaze.</p><p>Some 40 reinforcements have been called in from as far as the Alberta boundary, to Surrey in suburban Vancouver.</p><p>Salmon Arm city streets were largely deserted by yesterday except for emergency workers and a few stragglers. But some planned to defy both the flames and police.</p><p>"I'm sticking around," said one resident who didn't want to be named. "It's my house. I paid for that damn thing."</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier The 130-kilometre by 50-kilometre island is the largest in the archipelago.</p><p>The Galapagos Islands, a collection of 13 large islands and scores of smaller islets located1,000 kilometres west of the coast of Ecuador, are home to such endangered species as the giant sea tortoise, marine iguana and flightless cormorant.</p><p>In 1985, a 48-day fire in the Galapagos destroyed 20,000 hectares of urn:contentItem:4SKS-J940-TX4V-K1PM-00000-00Investigators say ATV rally possibly caused massive Manitoba forest fire2008-05-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:55:07ZLexisNexisGENERAL AND NATIONAL NEWSInvestigators say ATV rally possibly caused massive Manitoba forest fireCP

WINNIPEG _ Suspicious Manitobans are pointing the finger of blame for a massive forest fire on an all-terrain vehicle rally that was held in a provincial forest over the weekend.

The Woodridge fire got rolling Saturday in dry grass in the Sandilands Provincial Forest, then leapt into the tree tops where it was pushed along by a brisk wind.

Light rain has helped dampen the brush fire in southeast Manitoba, but one fire official says it could be days before it's brought under control.

Tom Mirus, manager of the province's conservation fire program, says the fire was caused by humans and investigators are trying to determine if the ATV derby being held in the forest may have sparked the blaze.

''It's just the heat from a muffler against the dry grass and you've got a fire. They don't even realize they've started a fire,'' Mirus explained about how an ATV can spark a blaze.

The fire, which has burned more than 28-square kilometres, was reduced to a smouldering blaze after 4.5 millimetres of rain fell Saturday night.

Mirus said the fire does not pose a direct threat to any community in the area and there have been no evacuations.

Marvin Hovorka, a local reeve, said there were 600 four-wheelers racing through the forest on Saturday, and he holds the derby's organizers and conservation officials equally responsible.

''Conservation is quick to ticket you if you have a bonfire, but this? They seem to stand back and say the public has a right to get out and four wheel. And when there's a hazard to the forest they don't get in a shut 'er down,'' Hovorka said.

A call to the organizer of the rally was not returned.

Conservation officials were careful Sunday night to point out they had to look at other possible causes, too, such as a lit cigarette thrown from a car window.

''We're not looking at just the ATV derby but there were 600 ATVs in that area where there were dry conditions (and) we are highly suspicious that is probably our cause. But until our investigators find out we really can't point any fingers,'' Mirus said.

Conservation officials said the Manitoba Forest Act, unlike laws regulating provincial parks, doesn't require permits for any recreational activity like ATV derbies.

Mirus said after crews finally put the fire out and pin down the cause, officials may need to take a second look at the law.

(Winnipeg Free Press)

urn:contentItem:531V-8N51-JCBG-93TN-00000-00Northern Saskatchewan residents set to go home after forest fire threat lessens2011-06-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:55:07ZLexisNexisWESTERN GENERAL NEWSNorthern Saskatchewan residents set to go home after forest fire threat lessensCP

WOLLASTON LAKE, Sask. _ Nearly 1,200 northern Saskatchewan residents who were forced to flee their communities because of a forest fire were getting ready to go home Monday.

Officials said that people who fled from Wollaston Lake and the nearby Hatchet Lake reserve would be flown back starting Tuesday. Store owners and others critical to getting things up and running again were to be first in line, said Norm Vetter, emergency Social Services manager.

''There are a number of other key community people that need to return to help the community organize ... and help personnel to operate the health clinic,'' said Vetter.

''There have been a number of those people that are identified that it's critical to get them in right up front. Then we'll be looking at the general population and develop a strategy on that.''

Wollaston Lake is about 840 kilometres north of Saskatoon and can only be reached by air at this time of year. Almost everyone was airlifted out last week to shelters in Saskatoon and Prince Albert when the fire flared at the edge of town. Military aircraft were called to help when smoke closed the airport.

The fire, which was first reported to Saskatchewan Environment on May 30, had eaten through roughly 45 square kilometres by Monday. It was fuelled by bone-dry conditions in grass, bushes and trees.

The fire was still considered out of control, but hadn't grown in recent days.

Steve Roberts, the province's head of wildfire management, said the fire was burning away from the communities.

''A fire control perimeter has been established around the communities and the airport. Direct threat from the wildfire has been reduced, but smoke will continue to remain an issue over the coming week or beyond, depending on weather,'' he said in a conference call.

There are about 30 homes in the hamlet of Wollaston Lake and another 193 on the reserve. Firefighters saved all the buildings, said Roberts.

Lightning has been ruled out as the cause of the fire. Roberts has said that the blaze was started by human activity, but it's not clear if it was accidental or intentional. A team of investigators was flown in Thursday to look at a forested area, near the end of the airstrip, where the fire started.

It's expected to take a couple of days to fly everyone back. Some high-risk people, such as small children or individuals with respiratory problems, may not go back right away because of the smoke.

Richard Kent, commissioner of emergency and protective services with the Prince Albert Grand Council, said people are anxious to go home.

''The evacuees have been looking forward to getting home, but they do understand and they were told that there will be smoke issues and the people that will be heading home will brought back in an orderly fashion by priority,'' said Kent.

''That's the way we pulled people out ... and that's the way we'll be going back.''

_ By Jennifer Graham in Regina
